|[[Marvelous pigments|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/marvelous-pigments]] with 3 pots and a brush [[Karalkhul]]|
and

|Yugtug Ring |[[Ring of Animal Transformation]] into a [[frog]]|
|Spell Scroll |(Detect Poison and Disease) (common, dmg 200)|
113 gp; 139 sp; 156 cp






Pat

Dwarf Wizard






Seppuku or Suicide

A PC can make an attack with advantage and automatic critical against themselves for this extremely strong compulsion.






Kindred Bracelets: When two people are wearing one of these bracelets each they are always aware of when the other is in life-threatening danger.






https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/knight<br/>

Medium humanoid (any race), any alignment<br/>

Armor Class 18 (Plate)<br/>
Hit Points 52 (8d8 + 16)<br/>
Speed 30 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 16 (+3) | 11 (+0) | 14 (+2) | 11 (+0) | 11 (+0) | 15 (+2) |

''Saving Throws'' CON +4, WIS +2<br/>
''Senses'' Passive Perception 10<br/>
''Languages'' Any one language (usually Common)<br/>
''Challenge'' 3 (700 XP)

''Brave''. The knight has advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The knight makes two melee attacks.

''Greatsword''. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) slashing damage.

''Heavy Crossbow''. Ranged Weapon Attack: +2 to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d10) piercing damage.

''Leadership (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)''. For 1 minute, the knight can utter a special command or warning whenever a nonhostile creature that it can see within 30 feet of it makes an attack roll or a saving throw. The creature can add a d4 to its roll provided it can hear and understand the knight. A creature can benefit from only one Leadership die at a time. This effect ends if the knight is incapacitated.

!!!Reactions
''Parry''. The knight adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the knight must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.








[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/a6g0ngm6vgojqxb/Kobold.jpeg?raw=1]]
Small humanoid (kobold), lawful evil

Armor Class 12<br/>
Hit Points 5 (2d6 - 2)<br/>
Speed 30ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 7 (-2) | 15 (+2) | 9 (-1) | 8 (-1) | 7 (-2) | 8 (-1) |

''Senses'' Darkvision 60 ft., Passive Perception 8<br/>
''Languages'' Common, Draconic<br/>
''Challenge'' 1/8 (25 XP)

''Sunlight Sensitivity''. While in sunlight, the kobold has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

''Pack Tactics''. The kobold has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the kobold's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.


!!!Actions
''Dagger''. Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) piercing damage.

''Sling''. Ranged Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) bludgeoning damage.








[[demonplague-touched kraken]]






As the characters leave the city, they see
a looming shape rise out of the ruins. [[Carozon]], a [[demonplague-touched kraken]] (see Appendix B, page 14), begins
pursuing them as they make their way through the city. The kraken chases them to the city limits, but if the characters leave the city, the undead beast mysteriously stops at the border, eventually turning and disappearing back into the ruins.






The knights of the Last Bastion Keep
left a terrible secret in the ruins of their crumbling keep. [[Sir Brenarfom Steelcrest]] captured [[Vera Sanguis]], a [[vampire]] (SRD pg. 352) that stalked the valley decades ago. The public believes she has been put to death, but the knights know Brenarfom starved and tortured Vera for information about evil creatures in the valley. Long after the undead woman told the knights all she knew, Brenarfom kept her alive and continued her torture, receiving a sadist’s pleasure by hurting the nearly immortal vampire. When the city was evacuated, [[Vera]] broke free of her prison. She stays in the shadow of the keep’s ruins, feasting on bandits that get too close.

If the characters approach, she uses her Charm action to get one of the characters on her side before screaming and cursing about the crimes of [[Brenarfom]] as she attacks. A successful DC 15 Charisma (Deception or Persuasion) check made as an action, and a promise to bring [[Brenarfom]] to [[Vera]], gets her to stop attacking. She would like to take her revenge on the knight. If the characters bring [[Brenarfom]] to her, she kills the knight and rewards the characters by giving them 500 pp she found in a chest in the keep ruins.
 






Warden
Male Lightfoot Halfling, Chaotic Neutral<br/>

Armor Class: 15 (Studded leather)

Hit Points: 52 (8d8 +16)

Speed: 25ft (7,5m / 5 sqr)

Proficiency: +3

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 12 (+1) | 16 (+3) | 16 (+3) | 12 (+1) | 20 (+5) | 15 (+2) |

''Skills and feats'':  Nature +3, Survival +8, Climb +1, Craft (Blacksmithing) +4,
Handle Animal +8, Hide +6, Jump +1, Knowledge (Nature) +7,
Listen +7, Stealth +5, Ride +12, Spot +5; Alertness,
Spell Penetration, Weapon Finesse.


''Languages Spoken'':  Common, Druidic, Halfling.


!!Actions
''Quarterstaff''. Melee Weapon Attack +3 to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. Hit: 4 (1d6 +1 ) bludgeoning damage.

Properties: Versatile (1d8),


!!Spells
''Spellcasting''. the Warden is an 8th-level druid. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save DC 15, to hit with spell attacks +7)

Cantrips (at will): [[Produce Flame|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/produce-flame]], [[Resistance|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/resistance]], [[Druidcraft|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/druidcraft]], [[Mending|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/mending]],

1st level (4 slots): [[Charm Person|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/charm-person]], [[Purify Food and Drink|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/purify-food-and-drink]],

2nd level (3 slots): [[Enhance Ability|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/enhance-ability]], [[Gust of Wind|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/gust-of-wind]], [[Spike Growth|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/spike-growth]],

3rd level (3 slots): [[Water Breathing|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/water-breathing]], [[Speak with Plants|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/speak-with-plants]], [[Haste|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/haste]], [[Meld into Stone|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/meld-into-stone]],

4th level (2 slots): [[Wall of Fire|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/wall-of-fire]], [[Freedom of Movement|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/freedom-of-movement]],


!Special Abilities
''Verdant Keeper'': Due to his connection with nature the Warden can cast a ritual that can greatly increase the growth of a animal or a plant. For each hour focusing the ritual, the creature grows 10% of its expected livespawn. Wardens usually retires themselves to regrow a entire region with months of work.

''Animal Friend'': As an action the Warden can charm a small or smaller animal to follow some simple orders. The creature must succeed on a WIS saving throw agains the Warden spellcasting DC. On a failure the warden can give a simple order with 5 or less words. The creature will only obey the order if it didn't show any kind of danger to itself. The charm effect lasts for one day. The warden can charm a number of creatures equal to its WIS.

''Wild Shape'': Once per day as an action the Warden can magically assume the shape of a beast that he has seen before. The creature must have a maximum CR of 1/4 and no flying or swimming speed. Same rules as Druid Wild Shape.

!Racial Features
Ability Modifiers: +2 Dex, +1 Cha

''Small Size'': small creatures should use d6 for hit dices

''Lucky'': When you roll a 1 on an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll.

''Brave'': You have advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

''Halfling Nimbleness'': You can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than yours.

''Naturally Stealthy'': You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.








[[Cadicca LeBlorne (deceased)]]






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/q068vfiu8dpekrp/Sentient%20Shield.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>
[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/0eaycf0hpjlc1ir/LeBlorne%20Crest.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>
Armor (shield), legendary (requires attunement)<br/>

The LeBlorne Shield is a sentient mithral shield decorated with the LeBlorne crest. It contains the soul of [[Zala LeBlorne]], [[Cadicca]]’s ancestor who was a heroic paladin. When Zala died, her soul was captured in her shield so she could continue to advise her family, but as the LeBlorne family aged, so did their corruption and the shield became more of a decoration.

You gain a +2 bonus to AC while you wield the LeBlorne Shield.

''Disease Immunity''. You are immune to disease while you are attuned to the shield.

''Spells''. While wielding the LeBlorne Shield, you can cast the following spells from the shield once each day (spell save DC 17): [[banishment|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/banishment]], [[beacon of hope|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/beacon-of-hope]], [[branding smite|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/branding-smite]], [[moonbeam|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/moonbeam]], [[searing smite|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/searing-smite]], and [[zone of truth|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/zone-of-truth]]. The shield regains the ability to cast these spells each day at dawn.

''Sentience''. The LeBlorne Shield is a sentient lawful good shield with an Intelligence of 10, a Wisdom of 17, and a Charisma of 19. It has hearing and darkvision out to a range of 120 feet.

The weapon can speak, read, and understand Common, and can communicate with its wielder telepathically. Its voice is that of a kind, elderly, proper woman. While you are attuned to it, the LeBlorne Shield also understands every language you know.

''Personality''. The LeBlorne Shield wants to protect those who live in the Luna Valley from evil creatures. Conflict arises if the wielder treats with evil beings.

The shield has no desire to be returned to Cadicca. Zala is ashamed of her descendant and would rather adventure with the characters than become a trophy or bargaining chip.

The LeBlorne Shield is impulsive when it comes to action, and encourages its wielder to never shy away from a noble fight, even if it means great risk of death.






Yugtug Goblin [[Vampire Warlock]], faction leader of the yugtug goblins in the [[Demonplague Dungeon]], can be found in [[DD26 - Legba's Hall]] normally.

* studded leather +1
* key to [[DD25 - Prison Cell]]
* emerald encrusted hip bone key to [[DD36 - Foyer of Xancrown]]

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1bUU_0YR40FWnuKWOA5FQ9nLkNuN5sDeAoswC_W1IJSk/edit






| d100 | Effect (lasts 1d10 × 10 hours) |h
| 01–10 |The character feels compelled to repeat a specific activity over and over, such as washing hands, touching things, praying, or counting coins. |
| 11–20 |The character experiences vivid hallucinations and has disadvantage on Ability Checks. |
| 21–30 |The character suffers extreme paranoia. The character has disadvantage on Wisdom and Charisma Checks. |
| 31–40 |The character regards something (usually the source of madness) with intense revulsion, as if affected by the antipathy effect of the Antipathy/Sympathy spell. |
| 41–45 |The character experiences a powerful delusion. Choose a potion. The character imagines that he or she is under its Effects. |
| 46–55 |The character becomes attached to a “lucky charm,” such as a person or an object, and has disadvantage on Attack rolls, Ability Checks, and Saving Throws while more than 30 feet from it. |
| 56–65 |The character is Blinded (25%) or Deafened (75%). |
| 66–75 |The character experiences uncontrollable tremors or tics, which impose disadvantage on Attack rolls, Ability Checks, and Saving Throws that involve Strength or Dexterity. |
| 76–85 |The character suffers from partial amnesia. The character knows who he or she is and retains Racial Traits and Class Features, but doesn’t recognize other people or remember anything that happened before the madness took effect. |
| 86–90 |Whenever the character takes damage, he or she must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be affected as though he or she failed a saving throw against the Confusion spell. The Confusion effect lasts for 1 minute. |
| 91–95 |The character loses the ability to speak. |
| 96–100 |The character falls Unconscious. No amount of jostling or damage can wake the character. |






Longstride Breeches: Anyone wearing these red breeches will never become tired from walking.






~~[[Outcome of the Election]]~~

[[Colinus Birthwitch]] & [[Thug]]s

~~[[Merriath The Quick]]~~

[[Ralekai Gravemore]]






A lost child has four levels of exhaustion and is a commoner (SRD pg. 398). The child is from one of the settlements that was wiped off the map by the melt, and
has no family left. If the characters return the child to health, they may be able to
find a suitable home for the kid in Tomar’s Crossing. Determine the race of the child
by rolling on the NPC Races table (see “Adventuring Party” in this section). Roll on the Child Behavior table to determine how the child acts once nursed back to health.

!!Child Behavior
|d6|Behavior|h
|1|''Bratty''. The child rarely wants to do what it is told and makes a big fuss whenever anything doesn’t go its way.|
|2|''Brazen''. The child thinks nothing in the world can harm it and often tempts danger and taunts monsters.|
|3|''Naughty''. The child enjoys playing pranks on the characters.|
|4|''Obedient''. The child does whatever the characters tell it to do to the best of its ability.|
|5|''Scared''. The child flees or hides at the first sign of danger.|
|6|''Vile''. The child is evil and will turn on the characters when the moment is right. Something inside this being has snapped.|






Rose-hued rain falls from the sky
during this encounter. Each creature
in the rain must succeed on a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw at the end of its turn or become charmed by the closest creature for 1 minute. A charmed creature can repeat this saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the charmed condition on a success. A creature who succeeds on its saving throw is immune to the effects of the love rain for 24 hours.






The Luna Valley is the setting for the Demonplague Campaign

[[Luna Valley Map]]






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/mwtbpc8ml6t6n31/The%20Luna%20Valley%20Map%20VTT%20SITES-II.png?raw=1]]








https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/mace-of-disruption






[[Yalea Merwit]], a chaotic neutral female human [[mage]] (SRD pg. 400), lost her tower on the outskirts of the city when the comet hit. The eighty-five-year-old demonologist inventor wears a mask of planar vision (see Appendix A, page 12) that she crafted herself. 

She wanders through the city looking for magic items to turn into new
inventions. Yalea tells the characters as much, and is willing to part with her [[mask of planar vision]] in exchange for any rare or rarer permanent magic item. If Yalea takes off her mask, her face appears to have no skin, a sight horrifying to behold.

Yalea is tough. She knows she may die in the city ruins, but she has no desire to leave the place she’s called home all her life. She no longer has a permanent residence in the city, but she seems happy to sleep in the various ruins.

If the characters show Yalea kindness, she chats with them, sharing the following pieces of information:

* Yalea used to work in her tower studying demons and using the energy of the Abyss to make chaos gems (see Appendix A, page 12), special gems that could restore a caster’s spellcasting power after they are broken.
* Yalea’s tower was guarded by gargoyles that now run amok in the city. They avoid her because they fear her power.
* Yalea has seen an enormous undead kraken walking the city streets, devouring anything it can get in its tentacles. She avoids the monster.

If Yalea is attacked, she casts the [[greater invisibility|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/greater-invisibility]] spell and tries to flee.






In a typical campaign, characters aren’t driven mad by the horrors they face and the carnage they inflict day after day, but sometimes the stress of being an adventurer can be too much to bear. If your campaign has a strong horror theme, you might want to use madness as a way to reinforce that theme, emphasizing the extraordinarily horrific Nature of the threats the adventurers face.

Going Mad
Various magical Effects can inflict madness on an otherwise stable mind. Certain Spells, such as [[Contact Other Plane]] and [[Symbol]], can cause insanity, and you can use the madness rules here instead of the spell Effects of those Spells. Diseases, Poisons, and planar Effects such as psychic wind or the howling winds of Pandemonium can all inflict madness. Some Artifacts can also break the psyche of a character who uses or becomes attuned to them.

Resisting a madness-inducing effect usually requires a Wisdom or Charisma saving throw.

!!Madness Effects
Madness can be short-term, long-term, or indefinite. Most relatively mundane Effects impose short-term madness, which lasts for just a few minutes. More horrific Effects or cumulative Effects can result in long-term or indefinite madness.

A character afflicted with short-term madness is subjected to an effect from the [[Short-Term Madness]] table for 1d10 minutes.

A character afflicted with long-term madness is subjected to an effect from the [[Long-Term Madness]] table for 1d10 × 10 hours.

A character afflicted with indefinite madness gains a new character flaw from the [[Indefinite Madness]] table that lasts until cured.

!!Curing Madness
A [[Calm Emotions]] spell can suppress the Effects of madness, while a [[Lesser Restoration]] spell can rid a character of a short-term or long-term madness. Depending on the source of the madness, [[Remove Curse]] or [[dispel evil]] might also prove effective. A [[Greater Restoration]] spell or more powerful magic is required to rid a character of indefinite madness.






https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/mage<br/>
Medium humanoid (any race), any alignment<br/>

Armor Class 12 (15 With Mage Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 40 (9d8)<br/>
Speed 30 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 9 (-1) | 14 (+2) | 11 (+0) | 17 (+3) | 12 (+1) | 11 (+0) |

Saving Throws INT +6, WIS +4<br/>
Skills Arcana +6, History +6<br/>
Senses Passive Perception 11<br/>
Languages Any four languages<br/>
Challenge 6 (2,300 XP)<br/>

Spellcasting. The mage is a 9th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save DC 14, +6 to hit with spell attacks). The mage has the following wizard spells prepared:<br/>

//Cantrips (at will):// [[fire bolt|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/fire-bolt]], [[light|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/light]], [[mage hand|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/mage-hand]], [[prestidigitation|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/prestidigitation]]

//1st level (4 slots):// [[detect magic|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/detect-magic]], [[mage armor|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/mage-armor]], [[magic missile|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/magic-missile]], [[shield|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/shield]]

//2nd level (3 slots)//: [[misty step|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/misty-step]], [[suggestion|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/suggestion]], [[spider climb|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/spider-climb]]

//3rd level (3 slots)//: [[counterspell|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/counterspell]], [[fireball|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/fireball]], [[fly|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/fly]]

//4th level (3 slots)//: [[greater invisibility|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/greater-invisibility]], [[ice storm|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/ice-storm]]

//5th level (1 slot)//: [[cone of cold|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/cone-of-cold]]

!!!Actions
''Dagger''. Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 4 (1d4 + 2) piercing damage.








1d6 purple boulders four feet high and three feet across are streaked with veins of red arcane energy. Awakened by the sound of battle, a mage stone acts on initiative count 0 each round. The stone casts a random cantrip from the Mage Stone Spells table against a random creature. When a battle ends, the mage stones stop firing. Each mage stone has 50 hit points, AC
17, and is immune to poison and psychic damage.

!!Mage Stone Spells

|d4 |Spell |h
|1|Acid splash|
|2|Chill touch|
|3|Fire bolt|
|4|Ray of frost|






The characters cross paths with a good- aligned magic creature that gives them a charm. To determine the creature
and charm, roll or choose on the Magic Creatures and Charms tables (this page, and page 37).

!!Magic Creatures
|d4|Creature|h
|1|[[Blink dog|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/blink-dog]]|
|2|[[Couatl|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/couatl]]|
|3|[[Deva|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/deva]]|
|4|[[Unicorn|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/unicorn]]|

!!Charms
|d6|Charm|h
|1|Charm of Animal Conjuring. As an action you can cast conjure animals. Once used 3 times, this charm disappears.|
|2|Charm of Evil Annihilation. When you deal damage to evil-aligned creatures they take an extra 1d6 radiant damage. This charm lasts for 3 days and then disappears.|
|3|Charm of Flight. As an action you cast fly on yourself. Once used 3 times, this charm disappears.|
|4|Charm of Healing. As an action you regain 3d8 + 5 hit points. Once used 3 times, this charm disappears.|
|5|Charm of Reincarnation. The next time you die this charm casts the reincarnate spell on you. Once used, this charm disappears.|
|6|Charm of Victorious Armor. As an action you gain 20 temporary hit points. Once used 3 times, this charm disappears.|






Half-Orc Gladiator

Armor Class 18 (Studded Leather, Shield (Master))

Hit Points 112 (15d8 + 45)

Speed 30 ft.

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 20 (+5) | 15 (+2) | 16 (+3) | 10 (+0) | 12 (+1) | 15 (+2) |

''Saving Throws'' STR +8, DEX +4 (+8 against harmful AOE spells, use reaction to take half damage save for none if it normally allows save for half), CON +6<br/>
''Skills'' Athletics +11, Intimidation +5<br/>
''Resistances'' resistant to all non-magical forms of bludgeoning, slashing and piercing damage<br/>
''Senses'' Passive Perception 11, Darkvision 60ft.<br/>
''Languages'': Common<br/>
''Challenge'' 5 (1,800 XP)

''Brave''. The gladiator has advantage on saving throws against being frightened.

''Brute''. A melee weapon deals one extra die of its damage when the gladiator hits with it (included in the attack).

''Menacing''
You gain proficiency in the Intimidation skill.

''Relentless Endurance''
When you are reduced to 0 hit points but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 hit point instead. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

''Savage Attacks''
When you score a critical hit with a melee weapon attack, you can roll one of the weapon’s damage dice one additional time and add it to the extra damage of the critical hit.

''Extreme Protection''
You know just where to put your shield to get the best protection from it. At 5th level, you are now resistant to all non-magical forms of bludgeoning, slashing and piercing damage. This can stack with additional resistances granted by other means. In addition, you gain an additional +1 to your AC when wielding a shield on top of the current bonus it gives.

You must be wielding a shield to use this ability.

''Master of Shields''
Where most warriors spend their time learning how to fight with weapons, you have practiced how to best utilize a shield for not just defense but offense as well. At 1st level, whenever you are wielding a shield and are not incapacitated you may add your shield’s AC bonus to any Dexterity saving throw you make against a spell or other harmful AOE effect. If this effect is a saving throw to determine whether or not you take half damage, you may use your reaction to impose your shield between you and the effect to take half damage on a fail and no damage if you make the save.

You must be wielding a shield to use this ability.

''Action Surge'': On your turn, you can take one additional action.

Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The gladiator makes three melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

''Battleaxe''. Melee Attack: +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 16 (2d8 + 7) slashing damage.

''Spear''. Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 5 ft. and range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d6 + 6) (Crit: 29 (5d6 + 6)) piercing damage, or 15 (2d8 + 6) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

''Shield Bash''. Melee Weapon Attack: +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 9 (2d4 + 4) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

''Javelin'' Ranged Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, range 30/120, one target.   Hit: 11 (1d6+8)


!!Bonus Actions

''Second Wind'' Once per short rest you can use a bonus action to regain 7 (d8 + 2) hp.

!!Reactions
''Parry''. The gladiator adds 3 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the gladiator must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.









Random Encounter
This hulking mammoth (SRD pg. 384) is starving and irritable. The animal fears
for its life and if threatened will fight.
If the characters ignore the creature it passes by without incident. If they feed
the mammoth, the creature follows them around until they run out of food to feed it. After feeding the beast, a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Animal Handling) check made as an action can convince the beast to attack a target or move to a specific place.
<hr>

! Mammoth
[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/ty6mz81yswqvwv3/Mammoth.jpg?raw=1]]<br/>
https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/mammoth
Huge beast, unaligned<br/>
Armor Class 13 (natural armor) Hit Points 126 (11d12 + 55) Speed 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |
| 24 (+7) | 9 (-1) | 21 (+5) | 3 (-4) | 11 (+0) | 6 (-2) |

''Senses'' passive Perception 10<br/>
''Languages'' —<br/>
''Challenge'' 6 (2,300 XP)<br/>

''Trampling Charge''. If the mammoth moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a DC 18 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone. If the target is prone, the mammoth can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.<br/>

!!Actions
''Gore''. Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 25 (4d8 + 7) piercing damage.<br/>
''Stomp''. Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 5 ft., one prone creature. Hit: 29 (4d10 + 7) bludgeoning damage.<br/>

A mammoth is an elephantine creature with thick fur and long tusks. Stockier and fiercer than normal elephants, mammoths inhabit a wide range of climes, from subarctic to subtropical.






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/nj88l4z9icti88p/House%20of%20Chaos%20L1%20VTT%20100dpi.png?raw=1]]
<p>
[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/kmdshldo1i05an0/House%20of%20Chaos%20-%20GM.png?raw=1]]






Found via [[Maragath’s Prize]] encounter

Ancient city of the Al Nasar Dwarven empire, located "miles" underground (the depth need not be miles for the entrance to be miles long).

Read or paraphrase the following text when the characters enter Maragath’s Prize:

<hr>//
A rush of stale air and the echoes of dead silence are all that greet you as you make your way down the steps of this tunnel that leads to Maragath’s Prize. You travel for what seems like miles, the world becoming deeper and darker. This place is so far beneath the earth that the lack of light is a black more pure than any you have ever experienced. The air down here is thick with the scent of death and the heavy moisture of rot.//

//Suddenly the stairs end and give way to a once- great city. Twisted dwarf skeletons, gnawed on and mutated by the demonplague, lie about
the streets. Ancient domed buildings stand
firm, with barely a crack even after thousands of years of neglect thanks to brilliant Al Nasar architects.//

//As you move down the street towards the newer parts of the city, you spy a massive sinkhole 50 feet across that descends into darkness. This
is the ancient entrance to the Demonplague Dungeon, uncovered by the Al Nasar dwarves and so many after them long ago.//
<hr>

The characters must descend 1,000 feet into the sinkhole to reach its floor and the entrance to the Demonplague Dungeon. At the bottom of the pit are more twisted, broken skeletons, but not just those of dwarves. Goblinoids and humans are in the mix as well. Read or paraphrase the following box text when they reach the door of the Demonplague Dungeon:

<hr>//
Amid the bones, a brass door that depicts a horrid grinning face with razor sharp teeth and enormous boils seems to be watching you with its eyes. It opens its mouth to speak. “Abandon hope,” the face begins in a demonic chorus of voices, “for your approach has woken Xancrown.”//<hr>

Choose an option based on difficulty:

!!Option A: (Very Hard)
<hr>//“As Xancrown’s agitators you may enter this place, but you cannot leave while Xancrown lives...”<hr>//

!!Option B: (Hard)
<hr>//“As Xancrown’s agitators you may enter this place, but you may only leave and return twice before being locked inside. Spend your time wisely.”<hr>//

!! Option C: (Moderate)
<hr>//“As Xancrown’s agitators you may enter this place, but you may only leave this place after obtaining one of five keys to Xancrown’s cell. Good luck.”//<hr>

Total value	1695 gp






When the time is right, you can run this encounter, which is the final encounter of Icefall. When the adventurers enter an unexplored hex, read or paraphrase the following:
<hr>//
Straight ahead of you is what appears to be a great mound of mud. Closer inspection reveals this enormous mound is actually a large rock, covered in dripping mud. An enormous circular iron door sits on the side of the rock face, covered in Dwarvish runes and an image of a crown. There can be no doubt. This is the entrance to Maragath’s Prize.//<hr>

The door to Maragath’s Prize can only
be opened with the passphrase “Iron is harder than gold,” spoken in Dwarvish. The characters know this information, but Fel’dryzonna does not.

The [[comet demon]] (page 92 — which appears as a purple beast with one enormous eye, bat wings, and huge black claws) and her demonic force, which includes one [[hezrou]] (SRD pg. 271) and 10 [[dretch]]es (SRD pg. 270), have already made it to the door and are lying in wait for someone to open it. [[Fel’dryzonna]] is keeping her allies close and using her Hidden Army ability to keep the group invisible. They wait for the characters to open the door and then attack.

If the characters spot the demons, they attack. [[Fel’dryzonna]] and her demons focus their attacks on one of the characters. If the character falls unconscious, [[Fel’dryzonna]] demands the other characters open
the door, or she will attack and kill the unconscious character. If the characters open the door, the demons resume the attack. The demons fight until death.

If the characters defeat or drive off the host of demons, they can access the door and [[Maragath's Prize]]






[[pseudodragon]]






[img[https://media-waterdeep.cursecdn.com/avatars/thumbnails/0/189/1000/1000/636252763036079032.jpeg]]<br/>
https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/marilith<br/>

Large fiend (demon), chaotic evil<br/>

Armor Class 18 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 189 (18d10 + 90)<br/>
Speed 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 18 (+4) | 20 (+5) | 20 (+5) | 18 (+4) | 16 (+3) | 20 (+5) |

''Saving Throws'' STR +9, CON +10, WIS +8, CHA +10<br/>
''Damage Resistances'' Cold, Fire, Lightning; Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing from Nonmagical Attacks<br/>
''Damage Immunities'' Poison<br/>
''Condition Immunities'' Poisoned<br/>
''Senses'' Truesight 120 ft., Passive Perception 13<br/>
''Languages'' Abyssal, Telepathy 120 ft.<br/>
''Challenge'' 16 (15,000 XP)

''Magic Resistance''. The marilith has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

''Magic Weapons''. The marilith's weapon attacks are magical.

''Reactive''. The marilith can take one reaction on every turn in a combat.

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The marilith makes seven attacks: six with its longswords and one with its tail.

''Longsword''. Melee Weapon Attack: +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) slashing damage.

''Tail''. Melee Weapon Attack: +9 to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. Hit: 15 (2d10 + 4) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it is grappled (escape DC 19). Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, the marilith can automatically hit the target with its tail, and the marilith can't make tail attacks against other targets.

''Teleport''. The marilith magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.

!!!Reactions
''Parry''. The marilith adds 5 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the marilith must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.









A Duladarin [[horned devil]] (SRD pg. 276), cares for [[Vaynala]]’s laboratory.






While wearing this onyx mask with the visage of a screaming demon you can see invisible creatures within 60 feet of you.

In addition, while wearing this mask you can cast the scrying spell (spell save DC 17) to observe any creature on any plane of existence. The inside surface of the mask serves as the material focus for this spell. Once you cast the spell from the mask, you cannot do so again until next dawn.

[[Yalea Merwit]]






Melgar the Quick. This master of melee combat is trapped by the Cult of Chaos in The The House of Chaos (see Chapter 4, page 34). He knows the components for the abjuration and evocation parts of the ritual.






The characters cross paths with a merchant caravan of 2d10 wagons making its way to Tomar’s Crossing from a place outside the Luna Valley. The caravan has two guards (SRD pg. 399) per wagon and three times
as many commoners (SRD pg. 398). The merchants are willing to trade with the characters and have many mundane goods available for sale, plus 1d6 varieties of uncommon and rare potions. Uncommon potions cost 100 gp and rare ones cost 500 gp.

!!Schedule
| 9 wagons |[[potion of mind control|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/potion-of-mind-control]] (beast) 500g <br>[[potion of diminuation|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/potion-of-diminution]] (3h) 500g <br>[[potion of healing|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/potion-of-healing]] (superior) 500g |






The melt cost Merixthalcast, an [[adult white dragon]] (SRD pg. 289), the icy defenses she had built up over centuries around her lair. Her lair and treasure are vulnerable now, so she stalks the area around her home for threats. She considers the adventurers dangerous and swoops down to attack, fighting to the death or until they flee.

The characters could attempt to find Merixthalcast’s cave, which should be full of treasure (see “Treasure” later in this chapter, page 55). Finding the lair requires a DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check after seeing the dragon.

This encounter occurs only once. If you roll and get it a second time, choose or roll for a new encounter from the appropriate list.

''Treasure''

13699 gp

571 pp

A mandolin made of a treant with inlaid silver and coral worth 400gp

a painting of a landscape in an ebony frame worth 250gp

a ceremonial rapier with a gold pommel with an inset topaz worth 100gp

[[Dust of disappearance|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/dust-of-disappearance]]

[[Potion of hill giant strength|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/potion-of-hill-giant-strength]]

[[Bag of beans|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/bag-of-beans]]

[[Wand of wonder|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/wand-of-wonder]]

[[Horseshoes of speed|https://www.dndbeyond.com/magic-items/horseshoes-of-speed]]






[[Merriath The Quick]]






!!Merriath the Quick ([[Ellie Mircar]])


Medium humanoid (human), chaotic evil<br/>

Armor Class 16 (natural armor see Draconic Resilience)<br/>
Hit Points 60 (8d8+24 see Draconic Resilience)<br/>
Speed 30 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |
| 13 (+1) | 16 (+3) | 14 (+2) | 12 (+1) | 9 (−1) | 18 (+4) |

''Saving Throws'' Con +5, Cha +7 <br/>
''Skills'' +4 Arcana, +7 Deception, +7 Intimidation <br/>
''Damage Resistances'' fire<br/>
''Senses'' passive Perception 9<br/>
''Languages'' Common, Draconic, Goblin<br/>
''Challenge'' 5 (1,800 XP)

''Draconic Resilience''. Merriath gains one extra hit point per Hit Die and her AC equals 13 + her Dexterity modifier. These numbers have already been factored into Merriath’s statistics.

''Sorcerer Magic''. Merriath has 8 sorcery points. As a bonus action she can spend 2 sorcery points to gain an additional 1st level spell slot, 3 sorcery points to gain an additional 2nd level spell slot, 5 sorcery points to gain an additional third level spell slot, or 6 sorcery points to gain an additional 4th level spell slot.

When Merriath casts a spell she can spend 1 sorcery point to cast it without any somatic or verbal components.

When Merriath casts a spell that has a casting time of 1 action, she can spend 2 sorcery points to change the casting time to 1 bonus action.

Merriath recovers spent sorcery points at the end of a long rest.
  

''Spellcasting''. Merriath is an 8th level spellcaster. <br/>
Her spellcasting ability modifier is Charisma (spell save DC 15, +7 to hit with spell attacks). <br/>
Merriath can cast the following sorcerer spells:

Cantrips (at will): [[acid splash|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/acid-splash]], [[dancing lights|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/dancing-lights]], [[mending|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/mending]], [[minor illusion|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/minor-illusion]], [[shocking grasp|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/shocking-grasp]]<br/>
1st level (4 slots): //[[burning hands|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/burning-hands]]//, //[[shield|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/shield]]//, //[[thunderwave|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/thunderwave]]//<br/>
2nd level (3 slots): //[[invisibility|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/invisibility]]//, //[[levitate|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/levitate]]//, //[[scorching ray|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/scorching-ray]]//<br/>
3rd level (3 slots): //[[dispel magic|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/dispel-magic]]//, //[[fly|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/fly]]//, //[[fireball|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/fireball]]//<br/>
4th level (2 slots): //[[dimension door|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/dimension-door]],// //[[wall of fire|https://www.dndbeyond.com/spells/wall-of-fire]]//

!!!Actions

''Dagger''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) piercing damage.






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/wqqx05crj96bk0d/Merrow.jpeg?raw=1]]
https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/merrow<br/>
Large monstrosity, chaotic evil<br/>
Armor Class 13 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 45 (6d10 + 12)<br/>
Speed 10 ft., swim 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 18 (+4) | 10 (+0) | 15 (+2) | 8 (-1) | 10 (+0) | 9 (-1) |

Senses Darkvision 60 ft., Passive Perception 10<br/>
Languages Abyssal, Aquan<br/>
Challenge 2 (450 XP)<br/>

''Amphibious''. The merrow can breathe air and water.

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The merrow makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws or harpoon.

''Bite''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d8 + 4) piercing damage.

''Claws''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (2d4 + 4) slashing damage.

''Harpoon''. Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) piercing damage. If the target is a Huge or smaller creature, it must succeed on a Strength contest against the merrow or be pulled up to 20 feet toward the merrow.










[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/d3uz3p7te178ivi/Messa%20Barristar.png?raw=1]]<br/>

Widow, Miller, Baker

Was depressed at her much older husbands treatment of her, freed by the characters.  

Took over her husband's mill.






[[Messa Barristar]] was in an unhappy marriage and considering taking her own life.

Her husband had contracted some kind of illness (probably the demonplague) and was cruel and paranoid.

The characters killed her husband, freeing her and she still lives in the mill/bakery and took over storage of some of the foodstuffs for the town.






The adventurers encounter a messenger (scout — SRD pg. 401) from a land far away who carries an important message for one of the citizens of [[Tomar’s Crossing]]. The scout offers the adventurers 50 gp to take the message to an NPC of your choice.
To determine the nature of the message, choose or roll on the Messages table.

!!Messages

| d4 |Message|h
| 1 |''Bill''. The NPC owes someone money. If they don’t pay up, someone could come looking for them. That NPC might beg the characters for protection.|
| 2 |''Dear Jane/John''. The NPC was in a long distance relationship and just got dumped. The NPC may try to have a rebound fling with one of the characters. |
| 3 |''Death in the Family''. Someone close to the NPC has died. The NPC may ask the characters to escort them to the edge of the valley so they can go pay respects.|
| 4 |''Payment''. The NPC receives a note worth 10d10 gp. They may give some of that to the characters as a reward for delivering the payment.|






The characters cross paths with a metallic dragon who has come to the Luna Valley for a specific reason. Choose or roll on the Metallic Dragon Age Categories, Types, and Motivations tables.

!!Metallic Dragon Age Categories

|d4|Age Category|h
|1|Wyrmling|
|2|Young|
|3|Adult|
|4|Ancient|

!!Metallic Dragon Types
|d6|Type| Ancient | Adult | Young | Wyrmling |h
|1|Brass| [[Ancient|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/ancient-brass-dragon]] | [[Adult|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-brass-dragon]] | [[Young|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/young-brass-dragon]] | [[Wyrmling|https://www.dndbeyond.com/search?q=Brass+Dragon+Wyrmling]] |
|2|Bronze| [[Ancient|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/ancient-bronze-dragon]] | [[Adult|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-bronze-dragon]] | [[Young|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/young-bronze-dragon]] | [[Wyrmling|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/bronze-dragon-wyrmling]] |
|3|Copper| [[Ancient|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/ancient-copper-dragon]] | [[Adult|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-copper-dragon]] | [[Young|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/young-copper-dragon]] | [[Wyrmling|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/copper-dragon-wyrmling]] |
|4|Silver| [[Ancient|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/ancient-silver-dragon]] | [[Adult|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-silver-dragon]] | [[Young|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/young-silver-dragon]] | [[Wyrmling|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/silver-dragon-wyrmling]] |
|5|Gold| [[Ancient|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/ancient-gold-dragon]] | [[Adult|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-gold-dragon]] | [[Young|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/young-gold-dragon]] | [[Wyrmling|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/gold-dragon-wyrmling]] |
|6|Roll twice on this table, ignoring this result if you get it again. The dragon appears to be the first type of dragon you roll, but actually has the statistics of the second thanks to mixed parentage.|<|<|<|<|

!!Metallic Dragon Motivations
|d4|Motivation|h
|1|''Knowledge Seeker''. The dragon has come to the area looking for knowledge. In exchange for any ancient books of lore found by the characters, the dragon gives them a charm (see “Charms” in “[[Magic creature]]s” in this section).|
|2|''Treasure Seeker''. The dragon has come to the area looking for ancient magic items. It might try to trade a few from its hoard with the adventurers. The dragon will not trade any of its items for items of lesser rarity.|
|3|''Scribe''. The dragon has come to the region to record events. It is strictly an observer, but offers the characters 1,000 gp each if it can sit with them for a day and trade stories. Any characters who agree to this also gain inspiration after sharing stories. The dragon will compose the tale of the Luna Valley into a book, song, or poem and eventually find the characters again to share it with them at the end of the adventure.|
|4|''Call of Xancrown''. In Xancrown’s fitful sleep he reaches out to beings of great power. This dragon heard his call and was lured to the Luna Valley. It has clearly gone mad and is obsessed with freeing the demon. Protection from good and evil, calm emotions, lesser restoration, dispel magic, or a similar spell allows the dragon to harness its inner strength long enough to break free of the madness. If freed from such madness by the characters, it offers them a piece of treasure from its hoard as a reward.|

!! Schedule
* [[Adult Gold Dragon|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-gold-dragon]] Scribe
* [[Adult Bronze Dragon|https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/adult-bronze-dragon]] Knowledge Seeker







[[Efreeti]] in [[DD15 - Micdo's Magic Emporium]], he is stuck in the Demonplague Dungeon like everyone else.






This cell holds Mikaladan Retrour, a female star elf (see Appendix B, page 13) captured by Fel’dryzonna in the Luna Valley before her people fell to Xancrown’s plague thousands of years ago. Fel’dryzonna
found Mikaladan and tortured the elf for thousands of years, until she revealed
the plan to trap and capture Xancrown in the Demonplague Dungeon. Mikaladan is ancient, but demonic magic has kept her looking young and broken her mind. She has moments of clarity, which allow her
to share her story and her people’s history with the characters (but only as much as you desire). No magic can restore her mind after millennia of torture.

[img[https://i.pinimg.com/originals/44/10/ae/4410aee6465f5572200e606d8bcb4e61.jpg]]

!Star Elf
Medium humanoid (elf ), any alignment

''Armor Class'' 16 (chain shirt)<br>
''Hit Points'' 27 (6d8)<br>
''Speed'' 30 ft.<br>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 12 (+1) | 17 (+3) | 10 (+0) | 15 (+2) | 12 (+1) | 15 (+2) |

''Skills'' Arcana +4, Perception +3<br>
''Senses'' darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 13<br>
''Languages'' Common, Elvish<br>
''Challenge'' 1 (200 XP)


''Fey Ancestry''. The star elf has advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can’t put the elf to sleep.

''Labyrinthine Recall''. The star elf can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The star elf makes two shortsword attacks

''Shortsword''. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) piercing damage.

''Invisibility''. The star elf magically turns invisible until it attacks or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the elf wears or carries is invisible with it.







A circle of thirteen druids called [[Minas Herion]], “The Valley Warders” in druidic, discovered the secret of the plague during the [[Raceon]] Empire. By searching hidden star elf archives, they learned of the plague demon [[Xancrown]], trapped deep within a dungeon in the heart of the valley, now located beneath [[Maragath's Prize]].

Their plan was to perform the [[Minas Herion Ritual]] gleaned from research in the star elf barrows. After weeks of preparation, they conducted the ritual during the winter solstice. It took a night of exhausting channeling and cost the lives of the entire circle. At ritual’s end, the entire valley became blanketed in a thousand-foot-deep sheet of ice. From coast to mountains, the ice sealed the valley and stopped the [[demonplague]] from escaping the dungeon.

The ritual turned the [[Minas Herion]] druids into ghosts. Eight have been slain over the past millennium by glacier dwellers, leaving five who haunt various sites around the valley. One of the ghosts is [[Feriae]], who currently haunts the Star Elf Barrows (having been moved from Fort Frostfell based on [[Ralekai Gravemore]]'s timeline) (see Chapter 4, page 125). [[Feriae]] and the other ghosts are key players in furthering The [[Demonplague]] storyline beyond The Frozen Necromancer.








Feriae the Wise can teach the characters to use the //ritual// to:

* Create a new dungeon similar to the Demonplague Dungeon that holds Xancrown to trap another demon like Fel’dryzonna. Casting the ritual in this way requires the casters participating in the ritual to succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw after the ritual is complete or die immediately. A creature who dies in this way returns to life as a ghost (SRD pg. 311).
* Bring another glacier into the valley – while this would seal [[Xancrown]] back in the dungeon, another comet demon could come and melt the land again. Using the ritual in this way will could the casters as it did the [[Minas Herion]] druids. Casting the ritual in this way requires the casters participating in the ritual to succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw after the ritual is complete or die immediately. A creature who dies in this way returns to life as a [[ghost]] (SRD pg. 311).
* Create a cure for the plague.
* Destroy [[Xancrown]], once he has been bested in combat.

The ritual consists of eight pieces. Each has a corresponding school of magic, material component, and word of power. The material components are arranged around a creature or location. A spell of any level from the proper school of magic must be cast on the component. 

Then the caster utters the word of power. The material components are consumed in the casting.

The ritual components were determined by the original human druids of the [[Raceon]] empire who created the spell. Each picked a trophy or object that was important to him or her and then chose a word of power related to the school of magic. The ritual was constructed in this way so that it wasn’t easy to duplicate.

|Druid|School of magic |Component |Word of Power |h
| [[Melgar the Quick]]<br/>[[The House of Chaos]] |~~Abjuration~~|~~A jade gauntlet sized to fit a human  ~~|//Far’ghul// (Draconic for “protection”) |
|~|~~Evocation~~ |~~The claw of a white dragon~~ |//Grac’smug// (Dwarvish for “explosion”) |
| [[Nalla the Gifted]]<br/>[[Gal'Nara's Tomb]] |~~Conjuration~~ |~~5 lbs. of purple farangi mushrooms~~ |//Alguhg// (Giant for “friend”) |
|~|~~Illusion~~ |~~The pincer of a glabrezu~~ |//Warbble’fete// (Deep Speech for “lies”) |
| [[Elial the Learned]]<br/>[[Emperor's Tower]] |Divination |A potion of mind reading |//Merowin// (Celestial for “future”) |
|~|Necromancy |The skin of a valok |//Azeel’rash// (Infernal for “alive”) |
| [[Targonoth the Brave]]<br/>[[Il'Shara's Retreat]]|~~Enchantment~~  |~~A pseudodragon~~ |//Nalinay// (Elvish for “charm”) |
|~|~~Transmutation~~ |~~Any magic weapon~~ |//Bar’noc// (Abyssal for “destroyed”) |


Jade Guantlet -- Statue of Il'Shara in [[Il'Shara's Retreat]]

claw of a white dragon -- [[Raljeviak]] in the [[Emperor's Tower]]

purple farangi mushrooms -- [[House of Chaos 5 - Cave of Wraiths]], [[Il'Shara 4 - Indoor Pond]], and [[Il'Shara 5 - Temple of the Dawn]]

pincer of a glabrezu - [[House of Chaos 10 - Cave of the Ancient One]]

potion of mind reading - [[Gal'Nara's Tomb 6H - Shelebaz Gal'Nara's Crypt]]

skin of a valok - [[Gal'Nara's Tomb 6A - Morga Gal'Nara's Crypt]], [[Gal'Nara's Tomb 6G - Zeva Gal'Nara's Crypt]], [[Random Encounter Schedule]]

a pseudodragon - [[Emperor's Tower 5 - Cave of Ice]], [[House of Chaos 4 - Elva’s Quarters]]

any magic weapon - [[Emperor's Tower 7 - Wizard's Quarters]]






[[Minas Herion Ritual]]






How to create a Minion Group, from
https://theangrygm.com/more-grist-for-the-mill-minion-groups-in-dd-5e/


''Minion Group''
 The [[creature group]] is a group of four [[members]] with identical statistics. Each [[member]] has its own space on the battlefield and each has its own hit points, which it tracks separately. Each [[member]] is also affected by conditions separately and constitutes a single target. The [[creature group]] as a whole cannot be targeted. The [[creature group]] rolls for initiative and takes one turn during each combat round. During the [[creature group’s]] turn, any or all of the [[members]] may move, provided the total movement taken by all of the [[members]] does not exceed the [[creature group’s]] speed. Any [[member]] may take the [[creature group’s]] action and, if the [[creature group]] is entitled to multiple actions or attacks, those actions or attacks may all be taken by one [[member]] or may be divided between multiple [[members]]. The [[creature group]] may also take one reaction between each of its turns, and that reaction may be taken by any [[member]]. If a combat includes multiple [[creature groups]], you do not need to distinguish between the members of each [[creature group]]. Any member of any [[creature group]] may act or move on any [[creature group’s]] turn provided the total movement and number of actions do not exceed the [[creature group’s]] speed or allotted number of actions.






https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/minotaur<br/>
Large monstrosity, chaotic evil<br/>

Armor Class 14 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 76 (9d10 + 27)<br/>
Speed 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 18 (+4) | 11 (+0) | 16 (+3) | 6 (-2) | 16 (+3) | 9 (-1) |

''Skills'' Perception +7<br/>
''Senses'' Darkvision 60 ft., Passive Perception 17<br/>
''Languages'' Abyssal<br/>
''Challenge'' 3 (700 XP)

''Charge''. If the minotaur moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 (2d8) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 14 Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked prone.

''Labyrinthine Recall''. The minotaur can perfectly recall any path it has traveled.

''Reckless''. At the start of its turn, the minotaur can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls it makes during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

!!!Actions
''Greataxe''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (2d12 + 4) slashing damage.

''Gore''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) piercing damage.









[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/3ectqbm9f840tzu/Minotaur%20Bandit%20Captain.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>
Large monstrosity, chaotic evil<br/>

Armor Class 16 (natural armor)<br/>
Hit Points 114 (12d10 + 48)<br/>
Speed 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 20 (+5) | 11 (+0) | 18 (+4) | 12 (+1) | 16 (+3) | 15 (+2) |

''Skills'' Athletics +8, Intimidation +5, Perception +9<br/>
''Senses'' darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 19<br/>
''Languages'' Abyssal, Common<br/>
''Challenge'' 8 (3,900 XP)<br/>

''Charge''. If the minotaur moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn,
the target takes an extra 9 (2d8) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 16 Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked prone.

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The minotaur makes three attacks: two with its greataxe and one gore attack.

''Greataxe''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 19 (2d12 + 6) slashing damage.

''Gore''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (2d8 + 6) piercing damage.






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/eu0t5viq7pl2uaj/Minotaur%20Skeleton.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>
https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/minotaur-skeleton<br/>
Large undead, lawful evil<br/>

Armor Class 12 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 67 (9d10 + 18)<br/>
Speed 40 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 18 (+4) | 11 (+0) | 15 (+2) | 6 (-2) | 8 (-1) | 5 (-3) |

''Damage Vulnerabilities'' Bludgeoning<br/>
''Damage Immunities'' Poison<br/>
''Condition Immunities'' Exhaustion, Poisoned<br/>
''Senses'' Darkvision 60 ft., Passive Perception 9
''Languages'' Understands Abyssal but can't speak it
''Challenge'' 2 (450 XP)

''Charge''. If the skeleton moves at least 10 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 9 (2d8) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 14 Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 10 feet away and knocked prone.

!!!Actions
''Greataxe''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (2d12 + 4) slashing damage.

''Gore''. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 13 (2d8 + 4) piercing damage.









Monsters in the [[Demonplague Dungeon]] are converted souls lost to the demonplague. These monsters take on the appearance of the converted soul. A vampire might have the body of a goblinoid while a horned devil could have the body of a gold dwarf. Each time the characters encounter a monster and you aren’t sure of its heritage, choose or roll
on the Monster Heritage table. The monster can speak and understand any additional languages associated with its heritage.

!!Monster Heritage
| d10 |Heritage|h
| 1-2 |Duladarin star elf|
| 3-4 |Al Nasar gold dwarf|
| 5-6 |Yugtug greenskin|
| 7-8 |Raceon human|
| 9-10 |Present day Luna Valley humanoid (This creature can be any humanoid race you choose. There is a 5% chance the characters recognize the creature as someone living they crossed paths with who is now dead.)|







The muddy ground conceals a canyon filled with mud. The canyon is 10d10 feet deep, 10d10 feet wide, and 3d6 x 100 feet long. A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check notices the mud seems less stable around the canyon.

When a creature steps into the canyon, it must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or become restrained as it starts sinking into the canyon. A restrained creature can end the condition and escape the pit by making a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check as an action. An adjacent unrestrained creature can free a restrained one by succeeding on the same check, but if the unrestrained creature fails, it falls into the mud and becomes restrained.

At the start of each of a restrained creature’s turns, it sinks further into the canyon. It takes a Small creature two rounds after becoming restrained to be fully submerged, and it takes a Medium creature three rounds. A fully submerged creature is blinded, deafened, restrained, and cannot breathe. A creature continues to sink 5 feet at the start of its turns until it hits the bottom of the canyon. A fully submerged creature can move at half speed through the mud by succeeding on a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check as an action.

!!Schedule
| Depth | Width | Length | Treasure |
| 71 | 169 | 1300 | 700 cp, 9000 sp, 2500 gp, 140 pp, Bloodstone (50 gp), Moonstone (50 gp), Quartz (50 gp), Sardonyx (50 gp), 3 x Star rose quartz (50 gp), 2 x Zircon (50 gp), Potion of Invisibility (very rare, dmg 188)  |

| 19 |1d4 + 1 [[bandit captain]]s and 5d6 [[bandit]]s |13|
| 20 |1 [[chosen valok]] |14|


Schedule:

* 5 [[black pudding]]s
* 1 [[oni]] and 1d4 + 1 [[ogre]]s
* 1 [[planetar]]
* 1d6 + 11 [[winter bugbears|https://dndbeyond.com/monsters/bugbear]] and [[Shockwave stones]]







This area contains 2d4 mud pits. The muddy ground conceals each 10-foot- square opening of a 10-foot-deep pit in the path of the characters. A DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check notices the mud seems less stable around the pit.

When a creature steps into a pit, it must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or become restrained as it starts sinking into the pit. A restrained creature can end the condition and escape the pit by making a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check as an action. An adjacent unrestrained creature can free a restrained one by succeeding on the same check, but if the unrestrained creature fails, it falls into the mud and becomes restrained.

At the start of each restrained creature’s turn, it sinks further into the pit. It takes a Small creature two rounds after becoming restrained to be fully submerged, and it takes a Medium creature three rounds.

A fully submerged creature is blinded, deafened, restrained, and cannot breathe. A fully submerged creature can escape the pit by succeeding on a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check as an action.

Schedule:

* 3 [[Glabrezu]] in a [[Mushroom field]] 50x67
* 7 [[giant scorpions|https://dndbeyond.com/monsters/giant-scorpion]] in [[Love rain]]
* [[necrotic tangle]] on [[Broken ground]]
* [[chosen valok]]
* 6 +PCs [[white dragon wyrmling]]s






The characters encounter 1d6 + 3 [[merrow]] (SRD pg. 332) who can swim through the mud that covers the ground as easily as if it were water. The merrow are starving and attack the characters, fighting until half their number fall then fleeing.

!Encounter Table
# 6
# 9






The encounter occurs near an unstable hill or cliff of mud. Movement within 15 feet of the unstable area causes it to collapse. Creatures within 20 feet of the unstable area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw when it collapses. On a failure the character takes 22 (4d10) bludgeoning damage and is buried. On a success the character takes half damage and is not buried.

A buried creature is blinded, deafened, restrained, and cannot breathe. As an action the buried character, or any non- buried character adjacent to the buried character, can make a DC 15 Strength (Athletics) check to release it from the mud.






[[Mummy]]






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/4zgprymhlu7vvcx/Mummy.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>
https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/mummy<br/>
Medium undead, lawful evil<br/>

Armor Class 11 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 58 (9d8 + 18)<br/>
Speed 20 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 16 (+3) | 8 (-1) | 15 (+2) | 6 (-2) | 10 (+0) | 12 (+1) |

''Saving Throws'' WIS +2<br/>
''Damage Vulnerabilities'' Fire<br/>
''Damage Resistances'' Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing from Nonmagical Attacks<br/>
''Damage Immunities'' Necrotic, Poison<br/>
''Condition Immunities'' Charmed, Exhaustion, Frightened, Paralyzed, Poisoned<br/>
''Senses'' Darkvision 60 ft., Passive Perception 10<br/>
''Languages'' The languages it knew in life<br/>
''Challenge'' 3 (700 XP)

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The mummy can use its Dreadful Glare and makes one attack with its rotting fist.

''Rotting Fist''. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) bludgeoning damage plus 10 (3d6) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or be cursed with mummy rot. The cursed target can't regain hit points, and its hit point maximum decreases by 10 (3d6) for every 24 hours that elapse. If the curse reduces the target's hit point maximum to 0, the target dies, and its body turns to dust. The curse lasts until removed by the remove curse spell or other magic.

''Dreadful Glare''. The mummy targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. If the target can see the mummy, it must succeed on a DC 11 Wisdom saving throw against this magic or become frightened until the end of the mummy's next turn. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it is also paralyzed for the same duration. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Dreadful Glare of all mummies (but not mummy lords) for the next 24 hours.








A field of green mushrooms 10d10 feet wide and 10d10 feet long grows in the area where this encounter occurs. A creature entering or starting its turn in the area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of its next turn. A creature that fails
three of these saving throws in a 24-hour period becomes blinded for 24 hours.







The mystic altar at the back of the room controls the locks on doors and constructs in the complex. A creature can attune to the altar by spending 1 hour with it. At the end of that hour a creature not of Raceon descent must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer four levels of exhaustion. The dragon has rested and removed these levels of exhaustion.

While you are attuned you can do the following as an action:

* Know the number and type of any creatures that are not undead in areas 1–10 of this complex (but not their specific location). You do know the location of any constructs.

* Lock or unlock any door in the complex.

* Activate or deactivate any trap.

* Issue a one-sentence command to any of the constructs in the complex created by the ''Eye of Ogma'', that they must follow.






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/lcc2mhvn8khle06/Nalfeshnee.jpeg?raw=1]]<br/>

https://www.dndbeyond.com/monsters/nalfeshnee

Large fiend (demon), chaotic evil<br/>
Armor Class 18 (Natural Armor)<br/>
Hit Points 184 (16d10 + 96)<br/>
Speed 20 ft., fly 30 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 21 (+5) | 10 (+0) | 22 (+6) | 19 (+4) | 12 (+1) | 15 (+2) |

''Saving Throws'' CON +11, INT +9, WIS +6, CHA +7<br/>
''Damage Resistances'' Cold, Fire, Lightning; Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing from Nonmagical Attacks<br/>
''Damage Immunities'' Poison<br/>
''Condition Immunities'' Poisoned<br/>
''Senses'' Truesight 120 ft., Passive Perception 11<br/>
''Languages'' Abyssal, Telepathy 120 ft.<br/>
''Challenge'' 13 (10,000 XP)<br/>

''Magic Resistance''. The nalfeshnee has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

!!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The nalfeshnee uses Horror Nimbus if it can. It then makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws.

''Bite''. Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 32 (5d10 + 5) piercing damage.

''Claw''. Melee Weapon Attack: +10 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 15 (3d6 + 5) slashing damage.

''Horror Nimbus'' (Recharge 5–6). The nalfeshnee magically emits scintillating, multicolored light. Each creature within 15 feet of the nalfeshnee that can see the light must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the nalfeshnee's Horror Nimbus for the next 24 hours.

''Teleport''. The nalfeshnee magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space it can see.








[[Nalla the Gifted]]






Nalla the Gifted. This genius artist wallows in self-pity in Gal’Nara’s Tomb (see Chapter 6, page 47). She knows the components for the conjuration and illusion parts of the ritual.






You can use the following table to generate names for NPCs. You can use all three columns to create three-syllable names, just pick from two columns to create two- syllable names, or take a single syllable from one column to create a one-syllable name.
!!NPC Names

| d20 | First | Middle | Last |h
| 1 |  Gar- | -ir- |  -on |
| 2 | Mat- | -am- | -us |
| 3 | Thul- | -orn- | -a |
| 4 | Breg- | -ur- | -el |
| 5 | Rom- | -ar- | -ike |
| 6 | Jul- | -it- | -o |
| 7 | Wym- | -ay- | -y |
| 8 | Hil- | -oy- | -en |
| 9 | Yis- | -iv- | -dra |
| 10 | Ig- | -uh- | -ew |
| 11 | An- | -ah- | -see |
| 12 | Flar- | -ot- | -oo |
| 13 | Prex- | -oot- | -ime |
| 14 | Qit- | -ix- | -bex |
| 15 | Cal- | -et- | -eve |
| 16 | Krev- | -ex- | -man |
| 17 | Laz- | -in- | -uk |
| 18 | Ul- | -urk- | -ead |
| 19 | Ol- | -mer- | -ang |
| 20 | Din- | -gran- | -lo |






[img[https://www.dropbox.com/s/f58uzpdss9cuqt5/Necrotic%20Tangle.png?raw=1]]

Huge plant, chaotic evil<br/>
''Armor Class'' 18 (natural armor)<br/>
''Hit Points'' 195 (17d12 + 85)<br/>
''Speed'' 30 ft., burrow 30 ft., climb 30 ft<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA |h
| 24 (+7) | 10 (+0) | 20 (+5) | 3 (−4) | 10 (+0) | 5 (−3) |

''Saving Throws'' Dex +5, Con +10<br/>
''Damage Resistances'' bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from non-magical attacks<br/>
''Damage Immunities'' poison, necrotic <br/>
''Condition Immunities'' charmed, poisoned <br/>
''Senses'' blindsight 60 ft., tremorsense 120 ft., passive Perception 10<br/>
''Languages'' understands Abyssal but can’t speak<br/>
''Challenge'' 14 (11,500 XP)


''Amorphous''. The tangle can move through a space as narrow as 5 feet wide without squeezing.

!!Actions
''Multiattack''. The necrotic tangle makes two thorny vine attacks.

''Thorny Vine''. Melee Weapon Attack: +12 to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (2d8 +
5) piercing damage and 10 (3d6) necrotic damage and the target is grappled (escape DC 20). While grappled the target is restrained.

''Leech Life (Recharge 5-6).'' Each creature grappled by the tangle must succeed on
a DC 18 Constitution saving throw or take 28 (8d6) necrotic damage and have its hit point maximum reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken, and the tangle regains hit points equal to that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.






Random Encounter:

The next time the characters stop to take a long rest they wake in the morning to find thick, green thorny vines with black veins have grown over their bedrolls and bodies in the night. If the characters rest in a tent, the vines have burst through the tent floor. These necrotic vines are a result of certain plants being exposed to the demonplague. Their seeds froze in the ice, but they have begun to slowly grow again in the new mud of the Luna Valley.

The vines feed on the blood of the characters throughout the night. Each character must succeed on DC 15 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion at the end of the rest. A character keeping watch notices the vines growing with a DC 11 Wisdom (Perception) check. That character can easily remove the vines (or wake the others and have them do so) to avoid the exhaustion effect.






Offers the characters gold if they find [[Building Supplies]]






Goblin Norker

Small Humanoid (goblinoid), LE

 
Armor Class- 16 natural<br/>
Hit Points (2d6+2) 11<br/>
Speed 30 ft.<br/>

| STR | DEX | CON | INT | WIS | CHA | S |h

''Languages'' Goblin<br/>
''Challenge'' 1/4 (50 XP)<br/>

 ''Nimble Escape''. Can take Disengage or Hide as a bonus action each turn.

''Sunlight Sensitivity''. Disadvantage on attacks and Perception checks when in sunlight.

!! Actions

''Studded club'': +4 to hit, (1d6+2) 

''Bite'': +4 to hit, (1d4+2)

''Rock'': +4 to hit, (1d4+1). 20’/80’

Small Humanoid (goblinoid), LE<br/>

''Hit Points'' (5d6+5) 23<br/>
''Speed'' 30 ft.<br/>

''Senses'' DV 60’, Perception +2<br/>
''Languages'' Goblin<br/>

!!Abilities
''Nimble Escape''. Can take Disengage or Hide as a bonus action each turn.

''Sunlight Sensitivity''. Disadvantage on attacks and Perception checks when in sunlight.

''Spellcasting''. 5th level caster. DC 13 / +5 hit

Cantrip (at-will): poison spray, resistance, thaumaturgy 1st lev. (4 slots): cure wounds, shield of faith, thunderwave

2nd lev. (3 slots): locate animals or plants, levitate, spike growth

3rd lev. (2 slots): meld into stone, protection from enengy
